instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.

threads.title: 00840 with 1.8V on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Need some help on this one.
This one had extensive liquid damage around the usual <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> area, but also around <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>.
Initially, the USBC chips weren't good so swapped one of them from one from a donor, this made it ask for 20V again.
I've replaced <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> because it was shorting <SIGNAL>PP3V3_LDO3V</SIGNAL> to ground (and the chip was getting hot). Have replaced it with one from exact same donor board, and short is gone.

I tried seeing in what state the board is now, but i'm not getting in S5. My <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> is measuring 1.8V. Anyone know how this is possible? There is no short there.

threads.title: 00840 with 1.8V on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I get nothing on pin 12 of <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>. that's what you mean right?

threads.title: 00840 with 1.8V on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: all resistors for that enable are fine, so i guess <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> isnt outputting the enable?

threads.title: 00840 with 1.8V on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Check basic signals and voltages for <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>.

threads.title: 00840 with 1.8V on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: checked if its getting its VDDs, but <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is shorted to ground (0.8ohms)

threads.title: 00840 with 1.8V on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
That is low enough to heat something.
Start injecting 1V and go high slowly, no more than 4V.
Let PSU current limit at max...

threads.title: 00840 with 1.8V on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yes i was injecting up to 2V @ 0.9Amps, but can't find anything getting hot, which is strange.. i'll keep trying tomorrow and report back.

threads.title: 00840 with 1.8V on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
2V divided by 0.8 ohm means 2.5A.
Discounting multimeter probes resistance, you should have 0.5 ohm aprox in fact.
That means closer to 4A even.
I'm very very curious how did you get injecting ONLY 0.9A with 2V in 0.5-0.8 ohm.
We may need to re-write Ohm law in such case...

threads.title: 00840 with 1.8V on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yeah you’re right so I guess my resistance to ground reading is a little off. Will check tomorrow.

threads.title: 00840 with 1.8V on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Remember to let PSU current limit at max...

threads.title: 00840 with 1.8V on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
doublechecked everything, not trying to rewrite nature's laws, but:
The short to ground measures at 0.76Ohms (my Brymen MM leads have 0.14Ohms resistance).
Still when i inject voltage (from a Riden PSU with 6A max) at 2V the board's taking 1.006A..

regardless of what 's causing this, something should be heating up at 1A but cant find any hot spots.

threads.title: 00840 with 1.8V on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
2V x 1A = 2W, not easy to find what heats with so low power.
You should get more than 4A going close to 4V; maybe 3.5V will be enough.
Just a simple formula, supposing 3A for 3V, that means 9W; should detect the heat for sure.

Anyway, remove CPU heatsink...

threads.title: 00840 with 1.8V on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: ok so i am putting 3.8V into this thing and the only thing heating up is the PCH.... shit outta luck i guess..
